direction.raw_text: Downwards and downwards until it skittishly circles a large, bustling park and then swoops us into the lavish gardens. There, a ten-year-old girl plays in the lush grass; she puts the finishing touches to a miniature version of the large park she sits in - benches made from twigs, trees from flowers, picnic cups from acorns - and gives a satisfied nod. She wraps her arms tightly around her chest, lifts her face to the sky, a half-smile threatening to break across her concentrated face. This is the young P.L. TRAVERS (whom we will also know as GINTY.)

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) --But I feel what's to happen, all

direction.raw_text: Her little brow is furrowed with imagination and then, all of a sudden, the smile breaks free as something in her mind becomes real.

direction.raw_text: P.L. TRAVERS sits in her rocking chair (in the same position as above) arms clasped tightly around her body, face to the sky. Older, beautiful; striking blue eyes aid her air of stiff and steely determination. Her office is a canvas of a life well travelled. Buddha smiles from every corner, framed poetry and letters adorn the walls alongside pictures of Pamela throughout the years with men we will not come to know and everywhere, china hens sit on shelves, their wings clasped to their chests, brooding. Despite the multitude of objects, the room is peaceful, white. Downstairs the doorbell rings. Pamela closes her eyes, breathes. It rings again, Pamela shakes her head, tuts. She stands up, smooths down her skirt with flat palms. Breathes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swoosh.

The barman talks with another customer further along the bar. Nobody notices Pamela. In this setting she looks like a little old lady, awkwardly perched on a stool, staring into her empty cup.

direction.raw_text: - BANK MANAGER INT. TRAVERS OFFICE - DAY Travers has just dropped (purposefully) a tray of coins on the floor. He has a wild edge to him, he may well have been drinking.

direction.raw_text: Bell Hatchett! Beautiful hatchet. That's what it means. And I suppose if the poor dumb lambs on his downs, are five minutes late with their calving, or they don't drop dead on schedule when he wants a roast, he takes to them with the business end of his beautiful hatchet. Travers wields a glinting letter opener in the air, stabbing piles of papers, filing cabinets, desks.

direction.raw_text: We share a Celtic soul, you and I. This world is just an illusion, Ginty old girl. As long as we hold that thought dear, they can't break us. Money, money, money. Don't you buy into it Ginty! It'll bite you on the bot! How did we end up here eh? Look at it. Barren. Breathless. Get as far away from this place as possible my love. Find yourself a patch of green. (HE SIGHS) It's a chimera you know? The world, the bank, you and I, Mr Randolph- whackety-whack-Belhatchett. All an illusion. He stares across the river, experiencing a wave of deep melancholy. Ginty looks up at him, aware of his profound unhappiness, but unable to understand its source.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another untouched meal in the hallway.

direction.raw_text: Pamela lies in the dark, the phone pressed to her ear.

direction.raw_text: I loathe this place, Mr Russell. How can a place so sunny be so cold? We don't hear what Diarmuid says.

direction.raw_text: I meant heartless. I'm afraid a jumper wouldn't suffice. It's bringing up these-- it's so hot and stuffy I feel like I am being attacked. These odd dreams, like my subconscious is after me. Punishing me for entertaining the idea that I might hand her over. I am at war with myself Mr Russell. (BEAT) The script is ghastly, exactly as I EXPECTED-- (BEAT) Yes, a few more days and then I'll

direction.raw_text: I know, I know I need the money. The money. The money. (TO HERSELF) Money. It'll bite you on the-- (INTO PHONE) It's all an illusion you know Mr Russell? All an illusion. (BEAT) Very well. Good morning and goodnight. She hangs up the phone, and continues sitting upright. Wide awake. Staring into the darkness. Pamela checks through her multitude of pill bottles for something to help her. Nothing. She groans as she drags herself out of bed, pacing the room, counting steps.

direction.raw_text: Serves me right. Money, money, money. Bit me on the bot. Her eyes stray to the big Mickey Mouse. She drags it onto the bed with her and climbs back under the covers, clinging onto the stuffed toy for comfort.

direction.raw_text: It seems enormously patronising to me. The very sort of annoying tune you would have playing in your themed park I daresay. All giddy and carefree, encouraging children to face the world unarmed. All they need is a spoon and some sugar and a brain full of fluff and they're equipped with life's tools. Wonderful! Dick is completely deflated.

direction.raw_text: What's your point Pam?

direction.raw_text: Travers! My point is that, unlike yourself, Mary Poppins is the very enemy of sentiment and whimsy. She is truthful, she doesn't sugar coat the darkness in the world that these children will eventually come to know. She prepares them for it, she deals in honesty. One must clean one's room; it won't magically do it itself! She waves the script in the air.

direction.raw_text: This whole script is flim flam! Where is its reality? Where is its heart, where is the gravitas? She opens a window and flings the script out.

direction.raw_text: Ginty skips up the path, clutching a brown paper bag. She ruffles Andrew's fur before entering the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ginty senses something wrong, she hears hushed, urgent and emotional voices in the hall. She pokes her head into the hallway. There, huddled together, whispering are her mother, the doctor and Aunt Ellie. Ellie is holding a pile of blood stained sheets. Ginty stands frozen, trying to still the panicked beating of her heart. Margaret spies Ginty and moves towards her as if in slo-mo. There are flecks of blood on her dress. She is ashen, shattered. She comes down to Ginty's level.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ginty cannot react. Margaret sweeps her into her arms and Ginty drops the brown paper bag; it tears and scatters pears all over the floor. Ginty's eyes fix on Aunt Ellie's umbrella on the back of the chair, drawn into its beady black eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you mustn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see him! Suddenly she turns into a wildcat - lashing, thrashing, biting, screaming. Nothing will stop her seeing Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let her go Margaret. Margaret is forced to let go and Ginty runs for her father's bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ginty stands in the bedroom, a long way from the bed. She stands there, it seems, for an eternity. Then, finally, step by step she draws closer. The empty bottle on the floor. The sheets twisted, still wet with sweat, flecked and spotted with blood. The front of her father's nightdress is also bloodstained. Ginty's eyes reach his face. Travers lies, eyes open, mouth open, teeth slightly red-stained, neither peaceful nor distressed. Just-- nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dropped the pears. She perches on the edge of the bed and takes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry daddy. Ellie appears in the doorway, Ginty addresses her without turning around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You promised you would fix everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A black London Taxi pulls up outside the house. Pamela climbs out of the car, struggling to pull her huge Mickey Mouse out too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela moves through the vestibule, lugging her suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela sits in a chair in the living room watching in darkness. She gently closes her eyes, ringed with sadness and a lifetime's despair. There's a knock at the door and she jolts awake, she doesn't know how long she's been asleep but it's black outside. She gets up and rushes to the door as quickly as her feet will take her. She swings it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh dear god! Standing on the doorstep is Walt Disney. Pamela is, quite literally, speechless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was one heck of a job getting a seat on the very next flight, let me tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, you always get what you want eventually. Isn't that right Walter? He looks down at her hand clenched into a fist and shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about you show me how to make one of those nice English pots of tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela sits at the table, as Disney carries in a tray with a teapot, a milk jug, a sugar bowl and two cups. These he places on the table and proceeds to pour tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milk. The milk goes in first. He attends to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And whiskey. I'll have whiskey in mine. Disney follows her gesture to the whiskey decanter. She takes it from him and pours a generous slug into her teacup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. (BEAT) Oh well, when in Rome! He pours a slug into his tea too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've come to change my mind. To beat me into submission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I've come because you misjudge me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do I misjudge you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look at me and you see some kind of Hollywood King Midas. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think I've built an empire and that I want to use your Mary Poppins as just another brick in my kingdom. You think I see her with a carpetbag full of greenbacks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that was all it was would I have pursued an cranky, stubborn dame like you for twenty years? I'd've have saved myself an ulcer! (BEAT) No, you expected me to disappoint you and so you made sure I did. You see, I think life disappoints you, Mrs Travers. I think it's done that a lot. Maybe Mary Poppins is the only person in your life who hasn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Poppins isn't real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, that's not true. She's real as can be to my daughter's and to thousands of other children-- adults too. She's been there as a nighttime comfort to a heck of a lot of people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Where is she when I need her? Hm? I open the door to Mary Poppins and who should be standing there but Walt Disney! He laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Travers, I am so sorry. I hoped this would be a magical experience for you, for all of us. But I let you down-- and in doing so, I've broken a twenty year old promise to my girls. (BEAT) I've been wracking my brains, trying to figure out why this has been so hard for you and I-- (BEAT) You see, I have my own Mr Banks. Mine had a moustache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah! Not true then that Disney created man in his own image?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it is true that you created yourself in someone else's yes? She doesn't answer. Walt takes mouthful of laced tea and coughs a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever been to Kansas City, Mrs Travers? Do you know Missouri at all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't say I do and as I have no plans to ever set foot on American soil again I'm afraid I never will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's mighty cold there in the winters. Bitter. Walt stops talking, catches himself, looks away and then gives in. His enthusiasm completely disappears and he's suddenly as ragged and as weary as Pamela.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (it pours out) My dad, Elias Disney, he owned a newspaper delivery route there. Thousand papers. Twice daily. Morning and evening edition. Elias, he was a tough businessman. A save- a-penny anywhere you can type of fella so he wouldn't employ any delivery boys, he just used me and my big brother Roy. I was eight then-- eight years old. (BEAT) Like I said, those winters were harsh and old Elias didn't believe in new shoes until the old ones were worn right through so-- (BEAT) Honestly, Mrs Travers, the snow would be up to here-- He gestures to his knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd push through it like wading through molasses. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the cold and the wet would be seeping through the shoes and the skin would be raw and peeling from our faces-- and sometimes I'd find myself sunk down in the snow, waking up, cuz I must've passed out for a moment-- I dunno. Then school, too cold to figure out an equation. And back into the snow so by the time we got home it'd be just getting dark, and every part of you would sting like crazy as it slowly came back to life in the warmth. My mother would feed us dinner and then it'd be time to go out again for the evening edition. (BEAT) Best be quick Walt, best be quick or poppa's gonna show you the buckle end again boy. Walt smiles at Pamela, sips his tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, I don't tell you all this to make you sad Mrs Travers, I don't. I love my life - it's a miracle. And I loved my daddy, boy I loved him. But, there isn't a day goes by where I don't think of that little boy in the snow and old Elias with his fist and strap and I'm just so tired-- I'm tired of remembering it that way. Aren't you tired Mrs Travers? We all have our tales but don't you want to find a way to finish the story? Let it all go and have a life that isn't dictated by a past? (BEAT) It's not the children she comes to save. It's their father. (BEAT) It's your father--? (BEAT) Travers Goff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you think you know about me Walter--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must've loved and admired him a lot to take his name--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Travers. It's all about him isn't it? All of this. Everything. Pamela looks at her hands, they're shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgiveness. It's what I learned from your books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't need to forgive my father. He was a wonderful man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you need to forgive Helen Goff. Life is a harsh sentence to lay down for yourself. Pamela looks down at the table top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give her to me, Mrs Travers. Trust me with your precious Mary Poppins. I won't disappoint you. I swear that every time a person goes into a movie house - from Leicester to St Louis, they will see George Banks being saved. They will love him and his kids, they will weep for his cares, and wring their hands when he loses his job. And when he flies that kite, oh! They will rejoice, they will sing. In every movie house, all over the world, in the eyes and the hearts of my kids, and other kids and their mothers and fathers for generations to come, George Banks will be honoured. George Banks will be redeemed. George Banks and all he stands for will be saved. Maybe not in life, but in imagination. Because that's what we storytellers do. We restore order with imagination. We instill hope again and again and again. Trust me, Mrs Travers. Let me prove it to you. I give you my word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela is alone. The unsigned rights papers in front of her on the table. She looks at Mickey who occupies the chair opposite her, her face softens under his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THREE YEARS LATER - DAY Disney employees pass by a giant movie poster which reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - OPENING SOON! Walt exits the building. He's but a few steps out of the door when Tommie appears behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt. She hands him a sheet of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Invitation list for the premiere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that everyone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not everyone. She looks at Walt questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll premiere in London as well. It'll be more convenient for her. Tommie holds his look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There'll be cameras, press, interviews-- I have to protect the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Walt walks away, he's lost a bit of steam. Tommy watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PAMELA'S OFFICE - DAY. Pamela taps away on her typewriter with gusto. She pings the return and breathes, satisfied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should say so too. The doorbell sounds, voices. Pamela begins to tap again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Mrs Travers! Pamela tuts, tries to carry on with her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (CONT'D) Mrs Travers! Pamela rises from her chair, smoothes down her skirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For goodness sake! She rises from her chair, smoothes down her skirt and makes her way to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't screech like an alleycat!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela and Diarmuid sit together. Pamela is quite changed, she looks younger, radiant, worry free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am so pleased to hear that Mrs Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should think you'll have a draft very soon. (CALLING OUT) Polly! Where's that tea? (TO DIARMUID) It's coming along marvelously! Polly kicks the door open with her foot and plonks the tea down in front of Pamela and Diarmuid. She sneezes twice, doesn't bother to pour and turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you pour please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're perfectly capable of doing it yourself. Polly leaves, Pamela rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's quite the worst maid I've ever had!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So why do you keep her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know-- she reminds me of me. Diarmuid laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a title?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Poppins in the Kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful. Should we start talking about the film rights? Pamela narrows her eyes at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. (BEAT) Now, tell me, Have you got your tiara for the premiere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'm not going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hollywood premieres are not for old trout like me. Anyway, it's not
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hasn't invited you, has he? Pamela doesn't reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Poppins wouldn't stand for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela is hot and bothered trying to wrestle her cabin baggage into an overhead locker. The same flight attendant from the top of the film appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm perfectly capable thank you. The flight attendant recognizes her with something akin to horror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suit yourself-- ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon and welcome aboard this flight to Los Angeles. Just a few announcements before we begin our taxi for takeoff-- Pamela takes the seat next to the window, she looks out at the tarmac. She closes her eyes, takes a deep breath, opens her eyes again and tucks her feet tidily together. She folds her hands neatly into her lap and looks straight ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt enters the outer office walking briskly towards his own office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning Dolly. Dolly opens her mouth to speak but he's already past and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tommie sits, arms crossed and stares, half bemused at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Tommie nods toward his office. Pamela is sitting in a chair, back to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me again!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt semi-recovers as quickly as possible and enters his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Travers! How wonderful to see you. What brings you to--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here for my premiere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't receive my invitation, but I just assumed the American postal service had fallen down on the job as per usual. She smiles sweetly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have a-- uh, replacement sent to your hotel right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's very kind, Mr Disney. I knew you wouldn't have forgotten me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pam, how could I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How indeed? You did, after all, assure me that I wouldn't be disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The porter lets Pamela into her room, and doesn't even bother hovering for a tip. Pamela turns and it's like deju vu - the flowers, the chocolates, the champagne, a VIP invitation to the premiere of Walt Disney's Mary Poppins. And, of course, the ubiquitous stuffed Mickey Mouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I left you in London.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela looks wonderful in a long white gown with turquoise silk gloves to her elbows and matching wrap falling from her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you call me a taxi please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely. The doorman goes to find her a cab and in his absence a limo pulls up to the kerb. Pamela doesn't dare get her hopes up but the door swings open and there he is, her favorite person in America.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Had a feeling a certain friend of mine might be needing me tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ralph! She rushes to him and they give each other a friendly hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like a million bucks! Let's get you to the ball. He opens the back door for her and she climbs in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's spectacular! Disney's biggest Hollywood opening. Bulbs flash continuously as limo after limo pulls up at the red carpet. Ushers are dressed as English bobbies. Reporters stand on podiums in colourful suits, Penguins dance their hearts out in front of the theater. Pearly Kings and Queens play for the onlookers. Crowds and crowds of fans scream every time a bulb flashes, waving their autograph books and posters in the air. Every Disney character imaginable bounces up and down the lines of well-wishers, hugging them, dancing for them, signing their booklets. Hollywood Blvd is completely shut down and the atmosphere is like the happiest party you could ever go to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ralph takes the car slowly through the crowds. Onlookers press their faces against the windows trying to make out who is inside. Pamela is nervous, everyone else has someone with them but Pamela must brave the crowd alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The limo stops at the edge of the carpet and Ralph jumps out. He rushes round to Pamela's side and helps her from the car. Immediately a round of flashes go off and Pamela puts her arm up to shield her eyes. It's too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in her ear) This is your night. None of this would be possible without you. She brings her arm down, straightens her dress and breaks into a smile, making her way down the carpet to frantic whispers amongst the press and autograph hunters of: "Who is that?" "Is that anyone?" Pamela spots Walt, Dick Van Dyke and Julie Andrews being interviewed together up ahead. Mickey Mouse bounces down the carpet and slows-- he and Pamela lock eyes for a brief moment. He holds out his gloved hand, she takes it and together they watch as a huge toy train chugs to a halt on the blvd and hundreds upon hundreds of coloured balloons fly out of it's roof and into the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pamela moves through the spangling, glittering, perfect toothed Hollywood crowd and no-one pays any attention to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The auditorium is jam packed. Pamela is seated in front of Walt Disney. Don, the Shermans and their families are in the same row as her - Bob Sherman next to her. The lights begin to dim. The overture begins-- We stay close on Pamela as the sounds of the overture fade and the melody of a single tin whistle playing one of Travers old melody's rings in her ears. We hear snippets of the film in the background but we remain with Pamela. She looks around at the faces in the audience - laughing, humming, sad, happy, joyous. Intercut with images from Pamela's childhood and the voices of Bert and Jane - Ellie's parrot head umbrella--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, begging your pardon, but the one my heart goes out to is your father. The carousel horses at the Allora fair--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There he is in that cold, heartless bank day after day, hemmed in by mounds of cold, heartless money. The tuppence and rolling pears--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like to see any living thing caged up. Uncle Albert with Ginty on his back, carrying her river soaked mother back to the house--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father in a cage? Ginty pressing the final bottle into her father's hand--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They makes cages in all sizes and shapes, you know. The image of the dead Travers in his bloodstained bed--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bank-shaped some of 'em, carpets and all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children in the audience, their little faces tilted upwards. Rapt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't ever leave us will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever would we do without you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall stay until the wind changes. And then an image from the film: George Banks walks away from us down the misty tree-lined London street, on his way to be fired from the bank. Walt Disney watches with quiet satisfaction. Pamela however has tears coursing down her face. Her shoulders heave as she tries desperately not to sob out loud but people are noticing, looking at her. Disney leans forward, placing a hand on her shoulder. She reaches up and grips it tightly, unable to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, Mrs Travers. It's alright. Mr Banks is going to be all right. I promise. Pamela nods in gratitude, but cannot contain her sobs. It's all pouring from her now, in one immense catharsis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. It's just that-- I can't, I can't abide cartoons! We stay on her face as we bring up the final song of the film: Let's Go Fly A Kite. The audience around her are smiling, laughing, singing along. Pamela, the tears, silent now, still pouring down her cheeks as she slowly begins to mouth along with the lyrics. And in her head one final image appears. Travers gaze falls upon Ginty, outside his bedroom window, sweeping. Their eyes meet for a brief moment, an unspoken understanding of what is to come, before his close with tiredness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Never. I promise. I will never lose you.
direction.name: direction
